data.title: Sun Brings Incubator Program to COB - Orfalea College of Business ...
data.meta_description: Sun Brings Incubator Program to COB - Orfalea College of Business ...
data.text: F A L L 2 0 0 0 R E C O G N I T I O N I S S U E A P u b l i c a t i o n o f t h e C o l l e g e o f B u s i n e s s • C a l i f o r n i a P o l y t e c h n i c S t a t e U n i v e r s i t y • S a n L u i s O b i s p o , C a l i f o r n i a Pendergast to Lead College of Business William R. Pendergast , most recently Dean of the Fisher Graduate School of International Business at the Monterey Institute of International Studies, is now Dean of the College of Business. Pendergast earned a bachelor’s degree in 1966 from the University of Notre Dame. He went on to Columbia University, where he received a Master’s Degree (1968) and PhD (1971) in International Affairs. Officially ‘hatching’ the Sun Incubator program are (left to right): Jerry Hanley, Vice Provost/CIO Information Technology, Cal Poly; Grace Caulfield, K-12 Education Program Manager - Global Education & Research with Sun; Shirish Netke, Group Manager - Strategic Business Development with Sun; and William Pendergast, Dean, College of Business, Cal Poly. Sun Brings Incubator Program to COB Sun Microsystems, Inc. has invited the College of Business to be one of only six universities worldwide to participate in their innovative new Sun (tm) Campus Incubator program. Sun Microsystems recognizes that the world’s top universities have produced some of the most significant companies in Information Technology in the past, and that the leaders of the network economy - the future leaders of the information age - are being conceived in business schools and engineering departments in major universities across the world today. Under the Sun Campus Incubator program, qualifying students will be provided a technical infrastructure to develop their e-business ideas with access to complete development environments that can be accessed through SunRay Enterprise Appliances, thin-client, front-end devices located on campus. To initiate the process, students must prepare compelling e-business plans and submit them for consideration to Sun Microsystems. Sun will highlight a select few business plans from every eligible university that has enrolled in the program. Based upon recommendations from faculty and venture capitalists, Sun will select the business plans that will receive six months of free access to the incubation facility. During this time, these start-up companies will develop their prototype or proof of concept for their business plan before seeking investors for their company. Business school students have a unique opportunity to turn their ideas into successful businesses faster than ever at a minimal cost to themselves. They also have access to Sun’s leading technology, as well as introductions to venture capital firms that could potentially fund these businesses. College of Business faculty and staff will provide support and guidance in business plan development. Once a young company successfully completes the first stages of its e-business application development and testing, it will become eligible s e e S U N , p a g e 3 Beginning his career as an instructor at the University of New Hampshire, Pendergast became a research associate at Columbia University’s Institute of War and Peace Studies. He taught at Boston University for the Overseas Program, where he held positions as assistant professor, Director of Academic Affairs, and Associate Dean of International Programs. From 1991 to 1994 he served as Dean at the Czechoslovak Management Center in Prague, where he was the chief academic and administrative officer of the first independent business school in that country. s e e D E A N , p a g e 2 Inside Alumni News .................................... 10-15 Calendar .............................................
